question: Question_01_(d)
statement:
Find the slope of the tangent line to $\displaystyle y = \ln(x^2)$ at
$\displaystyle x = e^2$.
sols:
Using the hint, we find the derivative at the given point. Applying the
chain rule we find

\begin{align*}
y &= \ln\left(x^2\right) \\
\frac{dy}{dx} &= \frac1{x^2} \cdot 2x \\
\frac{dy}{dx} &= \frac2{x} \\
\left.\frac{dy}{dx}\right|_{x = e^{2}} &= {\color{blue} \frac{2}{e^{2}}}\end{align*}

Using the hint, we find the derivative at the given point. In the first
step below, we use our logarithm rules to see that
$\ln(x^{2}) = 2\ln(x)$. Hence

\begin{align*}
y &= \ln(x^{2})\\
y &= 2\ln(x)\\
\frac{dy}{dx} &= \frac{2}{x}\\
\left.\frac{dy}{dx}\right|_{x = e^{2}} &= {\color{blue} \frac{2}{e^{2}}}\end{align*}
hints:
Remember that the slope of the tangent line is the same as the
derivative at the given point.
